p: Higher temperatures and greater CO 2 concentrations also promote the growth of aeroallergens (e.g., pollens such as ragweed and mold), leading to more allergic disease and asthma in children ( Shea et al. 2008). As noted earlier, aeroallergens can interact with O 3 to increase sensitization and allergic asthma. Both ambient and indoor air quality are affected by these increases due to the easy penetration of pollutants into the indoor environment.
